newsitem.title: DUBAI: Tajik government, opposition open talks in Iran.
newsitem.headline: Tajik government, opposition open talks in Iran.

text.p: Tajikistan government and opposition officials met in Tehran on Wednesday for talks on achieving peace in the turbulent Central Asian country, the Iranian news agency IRNA said.
Tajik Foreign Minister Talbak Nazarov, deputy Islamist opposition leader Akbar Torajonzoda and the United Nations special envoy on Tajikistan, Gerd Merrem, took part in the talks, it said.
The talks, the latest in a series of peace negotiations, will focus on ways of legalising opposition organisations, officials from both sides have said.
Observers from Iran, Russia, Pakistan and Uzbekistan were attending the talks which were expected to last 10 days, IRNA said.
A military deal was agreed last month in Moscow between the main protagonists in the four-year civil war. A four-month-old ceasefire appears to be holding.

In February, the government and the opposition hailed a preliminary power-sharing agreement reached after talks in Iran which gave each side an equal number of seats on a 26-member National Commission for Reconciliation.

The commission was limited to members of the government and the Islamic opposition. Diplomats fear the commission could sideline other groups, although legalisation of opposition political parties would give them a greater voice.
Tens of thousands lost their lives in the bloody civil war and many more were made homeless in the remote mountainous republic of 5.7 million people.
